author: Special Correspondent
text:
Chennai District Election Office receives reports of illegal posters and banners

The Chennai District Election Office has commissioned a facility in Ripon Buildings that will facilitate collection of data on election-related material coming out of printing units. However, election officials are yet to receive reports of such material being printed, from any of the 16 Assembly constituencies in the district.

But there is evidence that printing of such material is going on — something that is proved by reports of illegal posters and banners received by Chennai District Election Office.

“Political party representatives are worried because we are planning to factor in the material submitted by them while calculating the expenditure,” said an official.

The printing of election-related material is governed by the provisions of Section 127A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

Printers have been asked not to print or publish any election pamphlet or poster that does not bear on its face the names and addresses of the printer and the publisher.

Meeting

More than 100 printers participated in a meeting organised by the Chennai District Election Office this week.

Restrictions on printing of election pamphlets and posters have been imposed under the law. Punitive or preventive action will be initiated against persons who flout this rule.

Election officials are exploring alternatives to track unauthorised election expenditure by political parties, candidates and their supporters on the printing and publication of election pamphlets and posters.
title: Printers reluctant to share details of poll material
